title.narrative: Core support to CDRL - Phase II 2017-2020

description.narrative:
Det pågående kriget i östra Ukraina och allmänhetens krav på snabba och djupgående reformer har dominerat regeringens agenda 2014-2017. Under 2017 har reformtakten avtagit jämfört med tidigare år. De flesta politikområden nu står inför en komplex implementering av antagna lagar och förordningar. En annan utmaning är att skydda de framsteg som hittills gjorts.
Under perioden 2014-2017 har civilsamhället spelat en central katalytisk roll för att driva reformagendan framåt i Ukraina. Civilsamhället har utvecklat sin kunskap och kapacitet och fortsatt att pressa parlament och regering att implementera reformer inom centrala områden. Den huvudsakliga strategin för denna process är den reformvägkarta (Roadmap of Reforms) som utvecklades av civilsamhällskoalitionen Reanimation Package of Reforms (RPR) under 2014 med revidering 2016 med stöd av Sverige. Påverkansarbetet av det civila samhället har bidragit till att ett antal nationella institutioner mot korruption har etablerats, att en omfattande reform av rättsväsendet har påbörjats, att gasprissättning har avreglerats, att information om medieägare har publicerats, att en reform av systemet för finansiering av politiska partier har påbörjats, samt att en omfattande decentraliseringsreform och ökad insyn i offentliga upphandlingar har kommit igång.
Under 2016-2017, efter att parlamentet antagit mer än 100 lagar som utvecklats av det civila samhället, ofta genom RPR, har konsultationerna med civilsamhället institutionaliserats. Mer än 70 medlemmar av RPR-koalitionen har tagit en aktiv roll för att stödja implementeringen av lanserade reformer inom deras ansvarsområden. Under 2016-2017 har RPR-koalitionen även delat med sig av sitt framgångsrika arbetsätt till Ukrainas regioner genom användandet av en franchisingmodell och 10 koalitioner har etablerats i olika delar av landet.
I detta skede av reformprocessen i Ukraina är det viktigt att fortsätta att stödja civilsamhällets reformförespråkare och skifta fokus från lagstiftning till implementering. Genom stöd till Centre for Democracy and Rule of Law (CDRL) och RPR (ambassadens stöd till RPR genom CDRL) bidrar Sverige till fortsatt opinionsbildning och framgångsrikt genomförande av reformer genom att bygga upp starka och hållbara förändringsagenter.
Under en första fas av kärnstöd har CDRL förbättrat mycket när det gäller institutionell kapacitetsuppbyggnad. När det gäller styrning och strategisk ledning har organisationen reviderat sitt uppdrag och sin vision som utöver fokus på medierätt nu även omfattar rättsstatsprincipen och offentlig förvaltning. Denna utveckling av organisationen ledde till att den bytte namn 2016 från Media Law Insitute till Centre for Democracy and Rule of Law. Skiftet innebar även en omstrukturering av organisationens styrelse, vilken kom att inkludera tre nya medlemmar med olika bakgrund. Den nya styrelsen deltog i utvecklingen av CDRL:s strategiska plan 2017-2019. Organisationens stadgar utvecklades i enlighet med detta för att återspegla nytt namn, uppdrag samt nya verksamhetsområden. För att stärka det nya varumärkets igenkänning och få stöd för sitt arbete höll CDRL offentliga presentationer av den nya organisationen, deras uppdrag och vision. Med tanke på ovanstående bedömer ambassaden att samarbetspartnern kan hantera tillväxten på ett kontrollerat och bra sätt.
När det gäller utvecklingen av den interna kontrollen har CDRL utarbetat och implementerat ett antal policys och riktlinjer. Nya regleringsdokument omfattar informationssäkerhetspolicy, projektpolicy, styrelseförordning och evenemangshantering. CDRL:s organisationsstruktur har väsentligt förbättrats och innehåller nu tematiska företrädare för den strategiska planens alla områden. Den administrativa gruppen har också förstärkts för att bättre täcka de viktigaste funktionerna, främst strategisk kommunikation. Månadsvisa personalmöten och veckovisa ledningsmöten har införts för att förbättra den interna kommunikationen. På grund av organisationens snabba tillväxt har stor vikt lagts på personalintroduktion, som följer ett välreglerat och standardiserat förfarande.
Den operativa och ekonomiska styrningen har också förbättrats. CDRL:s finansiella avdelning inkluderar nu CFO (avdelningschef, organiserar och övervakar avdelningens arbete), Chief Accountant och Financial Managers. För att säkerställa kontroll över projektens budgetar har de delats upp mellan olika Financial Managers. Financial Managers deltar regelbundet i utbildningar om budgetering, rapportering, ekonomisk förvaltning genomförda av givare. Ett bra exempel på att organisationens interna kontroll har stärkts genom kärnstödet är att EU:s Delegation i Ukraina har bedömt att CDRL har tillräcklig kapacitet och expertis för vidareförmedling av medel. EU har anförtrott CDRL att hantera vidareförmedling till civilsamhälleorganisationer som är medlemmar i RPR-koalitionen.
NCG genomförde en effektivitetsrevision av CDRL i maj 2017. Baserat på revisionen bedömer ambassaden att CDRL är kvalificerad för en andra fas av kärnstöd. Den andra fasen kommer att omfatta genomförande av den strategiska planen 2017-2019, men också verksamheten för perioden 01.01.2020-30.06.2020 inom ramen för den följande strategiska planen 2020-2022 som ska vara utarbetad senast den 10 oktober 2019. De relevanta villkoren för utbetalningar finns i utkastet till avtal.
Det förväntade resultatet av det planerade treåriga kärnstödet till CDRL under perioden 2017-2020 är att stärka civilsamhället som ledande förespråkare av reformer i Ukraina. CDRL (bland annat genom RPR) kommer att aktivt sträva efter att stärka lagstiftning och procedurer inom mediaområdet, verka för större öppenhet och förbättrad förvaltning av offentliga institutioner, att stärka ansvarsskyldigheten inom rättsväsendet och ge juridiskt stöd för utformning och genomförande av reformer.
The ongoing war in the East of Ukraine and the public demand for quick and in-depth transformations dominated the government`s agenda in the country in 2014-2017. By 2017, the pace for reforms slowed down compared to previous years, as most of policy sectors entered a period of in-depth transformations and implementation of the triggered changes, newly adopted laws and regulations. Another challenge was to safeguard the positive transformations and progress achieved to date.
By 2017, civil society continued to play a strong role in advancing the reform agenda advocated by the Ukrainian people during and after 2013-2014 Euromaidan Revolution. Civil society organisations upgraded their expertise and capacity and continued pushing the Parliament and government to implement reforms in key areas. The lead guideline in this process has been the Roadmap of Reforms developed by the Reanimation Package of Reforms (RPR) coalition in 2014 and revised in 2016 with support from Sweden. By 2017, the accomplishments of well-coordinated civil society advocacy work included the establishment of the national anti-corruption institutions, fully-fledged launch of the judiciary reform, transparency of gas prices, disclosure of information about media owners, reforming the system of political party financing, triggering decentralization reform and enhancing transparency of public procurement.
In 2016-2017, after the Parliament adopted more than 100 laws developed by civil society, the coalition Reanimation Package of Reforms, a strategic partner for the Embassy in Ukraine, took on a new approach to implementing the reforms called "co-governance". More than 72 CSOs-members of the coalition took a proactive role and shared responsibility of the government for fully-fledged implementation of the launched reforms within their remit. Also, in 2016-2017 the RPR coalition started reaching out to the regions of Ukraine franchising the concept of RPR platform to regional CSO coalitions. About 10 such coalitions are being established, and the work on advancing reforms at the local level started following the success formula of the reform champion based in the capital.
At this stage of the reform cycle in Ukraine it is important to continue support to civil society drivers of reforms and change the focus from legislation to the full cycle of policy implementation and transformative changes in the society. By supporting CDRL (and RPR through CDRL) the Embassy would contribute to consistent advocacy and successful implementation of reforms, and building up strong and sustainable change agents.
The Embassy provided core support to CDRL (previously Media Law Institute, MLI) in 2014-2017. During the first phase of core support provided by Sweden CDRL grew notably in terms of institutional capacity-building. In terms of governance and strategic management the organisation revised its mission and vision going beyond the media law focus to embrace the rule of law and good governance. This evolution of the organization led to rebranding of the NGO from Media Law Institute to Centre for Democracy and Rule of Law in 2016. This change entailed re-structuring the NGO’s Supervisory Board, to include new three new members with respective background. The new governing body participated in the development of the CDRL Strategic Plan for 2017-2019. The Charter of the organization evolved accordingly, to reflect new name and mission as well as new activity areas. To enhance new brand recognition and gain support for their work, CDRL held public presentations of the new organization, their mission and vision. Given the above, the Embassy assesses that the cooperation partner is able to manage growth in a controlled and well-paced way. As to the evolution of internal controls, CDRL adopted and implemented a number of policies and best practices. New regulatory documents included the Information Security Policy, Project Management Policy, Advisory Board regulation, Event Management Framework and others. CDRL organizational structure substantially improved and now includes thematic leads for all the strategic plan areas. The administrative team was also enhanced to better cover the most vital functions, primarily strategic communications. Monthly staff meetings and weekly management meetings have been introduced to improve internal communications. Due to quick growth of the organization, due attention was paid to new staff induction, which has become a well-regulated and standardized procedure. As to operational and financial management, there were also improvements. CDRL Financial Department grew to include the CFO (Head of the Department, organizes and supervises work of the Department), Chief Accountant and Financial Managers. In order to ensure control over the project's budgets, the projects started to be divided between Financial Managers. Financial Managers regularly attended trainings on budgeting, reporting, financial management conducted by donors. A good example of the strengthening the internal controls in the organization through core support is that EU Delegation in Ukraine assessed CDRL’s capacity and expertise for forwarding of funds and entrusted the organization to manage sub-granting process for the CSOs-members of the RPR coalition in 2016.
NCG provided an efficiency audit report of CDRL in May 2017. The Embassy assesses that CDRL is eligible for the second cycle of core support. The second cycle will cover the Strategic plan 2017-2019 and results framework, but also the activities for the period 01.01.2020 - 30.06.2020 under the Strategic plan 2020-2022 and relevant results framework to be elaborated by 10 October 2019. The relevant conditions for disbursements are provided in the draft Agreement.
The indended outcome of the three-year core support to Centre for Democracy and Rule of Law in 2017-2020 is to strengthen the non-government actors – media and civic initiatives – as the leading drivers of reform agenda in Ukraine. CDRL (also via Reanimation Package of Reforms) will seek to proactively change the current legal framework and procedures to enhance the enabling environment for media, to achieve greater openness and good governance of the public bodies, to improve democratic accountability of the judiciary corps and provide quality legal support for reform design and implementation.

description.narrative: For the past 15 years, CEDEM has been guided by very clear values – being proactive, responsible, productive and unbiased. Every year CEDEM takes responsibility before society for analyzing the current problems of our country, we advocate for important laws and achieve results. In 2019, CEDEM continued to implement the CEDEM mission in ongoing and new activities that have become a platform for training civic activists to establish coalitions of NGOs in the regions of Ukraine. The plans that the ambitious team had set this year came to fruition and exceeded expectations thanks to their full commitment to working together. In a year of change and major political events, CEDEM succeeded in launching new projects and building partnerships to strengthen the role of civil society in Ukraine. The actvities have focused on three areas: • Rule of Law• Independent Media• Civil Society As 2019 can be referred to as the election year in Ukraine, the focus of organization's attention was the independent and unbiased media as well as the task of enhancing the role of the presidential candidates’ debate and the professional training of journalists in election coverage. The new President and Verkhovna Rada have opened a "window of opportunity" for media reform. Therefore, CEDEM’s experts joined the development and discussion of the draft law on media, which covers not only classic media but also online platforms. And the Center's proposals for political debate have been incorporated into the existing Electoral Code. The team is actively responding to the current demands, which is why in 2019 the Centre organized the first Open University of Reforms (OUR) for the assistants to the MPs of the 9th convocation. Participants in the project were 45 assistants to the MPs from the factions of "Servants of the People", "Voice", "Batkivshchyna", "European Solidarity" and "For the Future". The educational initiative itself is a continuation of the Open University of Reforms, an educational project that marked the 10th admission this year. Moreover, this year CEDEM institutionalized the Reanimation Package of Reforms. In late 2019, RPR began to function as an independent institution, which strengthened the association's ability to advance current reforms for the state. In addition, the first School of Communication for NGOs started in the autumn. In fact, a lot of applications have been received demonstrating an incredible involvement on the part of the sector. This may be viewed as a testament to the fact that public sector communication training is really in high demand. The year 2019, held one of the biggest challenges for CEDEM and "CHESNO. Filter the Judiciary!" carrying an analysis of all candidates for the position of a judge of the High Anticorruption Court. CEDEM's team submitted their monitoring results to the Public Council of International Experts (PCIE) and the High Qualification Commission (HQC). All information from the materials submitted by "CHESNO. Filter the Judiciary!" was considered at joint meetings of the PCIE and the HQC. During the reporting period, the CEDEM team implemented the Convenient Court project. Within the project, in cooperation with the Council of Judges, standardized information materials were developed to be placed in court premises. They will help citizens to better understand court procedures and help them to exercise their procedural rights. In December 2019, together with Uber, the CSO launched an initiative to raise awareness of the importance of wearing seat belts. In particular, CEDEM developed awareness-raising materials that were emailed to Uber drivers and passengers. Also, in 2019, the CSO launched a series of workshops for Uber partner drivers in Kyiv to improve their driving skills. At the end of the year, the organization also launched a new large-scale initiative that will work over the next five years. CEDEM co-launched a project “Ukrainian Civil Society Sectoral Support Initiative” in consortium with the Initiative Center to Support Social Action "Ednannia" and Ukrainian Center for Independent Political Research. Its main goal is to help the Ukrainian public sector become stronger and more cohesive.
